answers.answer: Hi,How are you? It is good that you were able to see specialists and had normal findings. However, it is important that your newly diagnosed diabetes condition be managed to prevent complications such as  peripheral neuropathies which presents with numbness, loss of sensation, and sometimes pain in the feet, legs, or hands. It is highly recommended  that blood sugar levels are within normal levels. Talk to your doctor about this for proper management.  Aside from diabetes neuropathies, osteoarthritis, musculoskeletal issues and vitamin B 12 deficiency may also be ruled out. Take care and do keep us posted.

question: I am 50 years old . from last 2 months i am suffering from severe back pain . the pain first started in my lower back with a single nerve paining till my knee . I have consulted local doctors of bones and nerve nothing unnatural  came in reports I am also diabetic (Type 2)  . they prescribed some physical exercises but it is of no use the pain in increasing g day by day kindly help
title: kindly help
